awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms and adaptive consequences of group decision-making in a communally nesting bird
awd_abstract_narration:
Solving collective problems is one of the central challenges of group living. When individuals prefer different outcomes, how do societies agree on one choice for everyone? Human groups have developed a variety of methods, from despotism to democratic voting. Collective decision-making in animal groups is less well understood, although examples are ubiquitous: a honeybee colony picks a new location for the hive; a monkey troop invades a neighboring territory; a flock of birds changes its roost site. Theoretical models have been developed to predict the conditions under which such decisions should be shared, and how the structure and stability of the social group might influence the speed and accuracy of these decisions. However, experimental studies on wild animals are rare, leaving gaps between theoretical predictions and empirical evidence. This project explores these gaps in a tropical bird, the greater ani. Anis nest in social groups composed of several pairs, which build a single nest in which all of the females lay their eggs. The choice of where to build the nest is a crucial decision, since its location determines its exposure to predators. The project combines field experiments, behavioral observations, and tracking techniques to test how groups arrive at shared decisions - and, crucially, which opinions prevail when group members disagree. This project will provide research experiences to students and a postdoctoral researcher, training to Panamanian researchers through a series of public workshops, and outreach to the public through a partnership with the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute. 

This project explores three major questions about collective decision-making that have arisen from recent theoretical work. First, do shared decisions become less democratic as delays in decision-making grow more costly? Second, can a well-informed minority exert disproportionate influence over group decisions? Third, how does social network structure affect the equality, speed, and accuracy of collective decisions? The research plan leverages a long-term (>10-year) data set on greater anis in Panama, which live in groups containing multiple unrelated breeding pairs. Some groups are remarkably stable, consisting of the same members for over a decade; whereas others consist of a mix of experienced individuals and newcomers. Anis show close affiliative relationships with other group members who are not their mates, and prior research has found that the duration of these relationships affects coordinated behaviors. In this project, conflicts of preference between group members will be created by manipulating nest-site quality and the information available to different individuals. This will enable hypothesis testing of how group members arrive at collective decisions when their opinions conflict, how individuals communicate preferences, and whether the presence of well-informed individuals changes the outcome of collective decisions.  Knowledge of individual life histories and natural variation in group stability, combined with RFID tracking data on interactions between group members, will reveal how social network structure affects the process and outcome of collective decision-making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Collective decision-making is a central feature of human societies. Groups of people must make shared decisions every day, ranging from restaurant choices to presidential elections. Social animals face similar situations: a honeybee colony chooses a new location for its hive; a baboon troop decides to change its sleeping site; a group of cooperatively breeding birds suddenly invades its neighbors’ territory. But how are these decisions made, and how do animals coordinate their behaviors to accomplish a common goal?

This project had three goals. First, we examined division of labor: how members of cooperative animal groups divide a shared workload to contribute to a common good. We asked whether certain group members specialize on different tasks, and whether labor was evenly distributed across group members. Second, we investigated coordination: how group members communicate with each other to synchronize their activities. Finally, we studied collective decision-making: how groups of individuals arrive at shared decisions. We asked whether group size or stability affected their ability to arrive at a consensus, and whether certain individuals were able to disproportionately influence the outcome of the collective decision.

We studied these questions in Greater Anis, a cooperatively breeding bird, in Panama. Anis (pronounced ah-nees) have a fascinating social system: several unrelated pairs build a single nest, lay their eggs in it, and share parental care of the resulting mixed clutch of nestlings. Adults cannot recognize their own eggs or young: they literally “put all their eggs in one basket” and cooperate to raise a shared brood. This species provides unique opportunities to ask questions about division of labor and collective decision-making, since the welfare of each group member’s offspring depends on the wellbeing of the entire group.

Using observational studies of marked birds, we first measured the amount of work performed by each group member in many different nesting groups of varying sizes. We found that individuals do not specialize on particular tasks, but some individuals work much harder than others. Whereas workload was evenly distributed in small groups, it became increasingly unequal in large groups. This is consistent with predictions from the collective action theory of sociologists and economists, but rarely shown in wild animal societies. We also synthesized this research into a larger paper that reviewed the literature on division of labor and workload inequality in cooperative animal societies, and highlighted areas for future research to bridge theory and real-world studies.

Next, we used observations and field experiments to ask how anis communicate with each other to share information about coordinated activities (like when to lay their eggs in the communal nest) and common threats (like nest predators). We found that anis use different types of calls to communicate different types of information. Group choruses were primarily used to coordinate within-group activities, including reproduction. In these choruses, all group members huddle together and call at the same time (similar to a pack of wolves howling). By contrast, anis gave very different calls to alert their group members to aerial predators, such as hawks and falcons flying overhead, and terrestrial predators such as monkeys and snakes. This type of communication is known as referential communication, since different types of calls refer to specific threats, and it is thought to be the most complex form of signaling in social animals.

Finally, we used another set of experiments to determine how groups of anis make collective decisions. We placed artificial greater ani nests near known ani territories and used video cameras to record the reactions of the real birds nesting nearby. Greater anis are territorial and will destroy the nests of nearby groups, but it was not previously known whether these raids are carried out by lone individuals or by collectives. Our videos showed that single anis often find these fake nests and can destroy the nests by themselves, but they often return with other group members. In conjunction with our previous research, we showed that group stability matters more than group size: large groups have no advantage over small groups, but stable groups are more likely to evict newcomers.

Taken together, our work sheds new light on how wild animals in social groups manage difficult feats of coordination and cooperation. We documented parallels with other complex animal societies (such as referential signaling, which is rare outside of primates) and general rules that may apply broadly across animal groups (such as the pattern of workload inequality increasing with group size). We published this work in 10 peer-reviewed journal articles and it formed the basis of 2 Ph.D. students’ dissertations at Princeton University. We engaged public audiences by giving talks to Audubon societies, bird clubs, and live seminars over YouTube, and we included undergraduate students from 5 different countries in our research. Finally, the results will be illustrated in a public exhibit at the field station in Panama.
